segments.text: On the day she was discharged from the Army, she was already at the beginning of her seventh month of pregnancy.
No one around her knew.
It was winter, and she always wore a large, long sweater.
Besides, she had barely gained weight, just a few kilograms that slightly covered her thinness.
The period of vomiting stopped shortly after it began, and from that moment she felt wonderful.
When the doctor returned with his positive answer, he sat opposite her and explained quietly, There is still the option of having an abortion if that's what you decide.
This must be your decision.
You need to understand all the implications involved in deciding not to abort.
You must consider the difficulties, commitment, and loss of independence and privacy.
You will have a child to raise, support, and worry for.
It's a big, complex package.
But it also comes with a lot of happiness and joy.
He paused for a moment and then added, especially when done as a couple.
With his last remark, a great sense of loneliness rose in her.
From that moment, her nights were filled with dreams, full of longing, and especially attempts to convey to Dan her feelings, her love, and her hope that he would return quickly.
As if calling him to return, he has something to look forward to, something to hope for, and one little child who will fill their hearts and call him dad.
She immediately knew she wouldn't have an abortion.
It wasn't possible.
This child came from great love.
Occasionally, she would place her hand on her stomach as if holding it.
Stroking, calming, and above all, she knew with certainty a son was inside her.
Without any doubt.
During one of Yosef's visits, she sat him down in front of her, held his hands, and said, Dad, I have something important to tell you.
I'm pregnant.
Yes, right, with Dan, whom I told you about.
The one whose oil painting you did was bought by the French ambassador and is hanging in his parents' home.
Only he's on some secret mission now for a few months.
There's no way to contact him, and he's likely unable to either.
It seems this will take a long time, which means I'll have to deal with this alone for now.
I really want you to be happy about it.
It wasn't part of any plan, but apparently it was meant to be.
There's great love between us, special, caring, deep, and sincere.
And maybe, maybe it's his way to ensure I won't be alone.
There were two weeks when I couldn't stop vomiting, but since that ended, I feel great and everything's fine.
Everything except the longing.
She looked into his eyes and found him looking at her with a mixture of amazement and admiration.
To her surprise, there was no anger in his face.
I can't believe I'm going to be a grandfather.
He smiled at her, still holding hands, sitting across from each other.
You'll need some help closer to the birth, and we'll need to take care of that.
You'll also need a bed, a stroller, and other things.
Suddenly, both of them laughed with such joy, and for a moment, he was once again her familiar father.
The concern of what will people say, which would probably arise for any other father, didn't exist for him.
From that moment, he made sure to call her at least twice a week and visited every two weeks to check she was okay.
And now she was leaving the army, exiting the base gate to the bus stop, making her way home from there for the last time.
In recent months, she asked the battalion commander to return to her previous position.
The person who replaced Dan was perhaps successful but arrogant, cynical, and lacking interpersonal skills.
He had something cold and technical about him, and she found no common language with him.
To her surprise, she found herself arguing with him, sometimes in a defiant and disrespectful tone, as if fighting against his unpleasant traits, aware she was unconsciously comparing him to Dan.
The battalion commander tried to persuade her otherwise, but completely understood her feelings.
If you ever need help, I'm here," she promised him.
He was worried about her.
Something had changed in her.
Since Dan disappeared, it was as if her emotions had entered a winter hibernation.
She was quieter than usual, closed off, withdrawn.
Yet he thought she physically looked better, as if she had gained a pound or two.
Sometimes it even seemed a slight blush appeared on her cheeks, which suited her very well.
He couldn't help her with any information about Dan.
He only knew that after their last activity, Dan was assigned to something secret.
Only later, it became clear this had been coordinated with Dan months in advance due to a golden opportunity that arose, a mission they had dreamed about for years.
He fit them like a glove, and they simply absorbed him into their ranks.
He had been briefed on this long before, but in his manner and likely as instructed, he didn't say a word about it.
They came to the battalion commander about a month before the planned operation and briefly explained that he had to let Dan go.
No way, he protested.
We've been planning this operation for weeks on end, and he knows every detail.
You won't get him even a minute before this is finished.
And they really didn't wait a minute longer.
They simply made him disappear immediately without giving him a chance to say goodbye or explain to anyone.
He knew it would take a long time, not a day or two, not just a few months.
More than four months had already passed.
What could he say to her?
He saw the longing and worry in her eyes.
She said goodbye to him, thanking him for a challenging period for the trust he had placed in her and finally quietly asked,
Keep looking after my soldiers as only you know how, with the misty look in her eyes.
Then she turned and walked away.
A chapter ended, the battalion commander thought to himself, two of my pillars have disappeared, and still he knew almost nothing about her.
Just as he intended to delve deeper, Dan disappeared and all the operational madness began.
He didn't have a minute to ponder about her nature, her home, her loneliness.

She got off the bus at the stop by the pink house, waving as she always did to duty the driver, crossed the silver pattern path, pushed the front door open, and knew this was the start of the rest of her life.
As she made her way to the kitchen, she suddenly stopped in front of Lucy's portrait, looked deep into her gray eyes, and said, don't worry, mom, everything will be fine.
Without realizing it, a faint smile spread across her face, and a calmness settled over her.

Here, for over a year, she's been keeping this house on her own, managing to make a living, and above all, maintaining the pink walls adorned with Yosef's paintings and the magical garden surrounding it, all of which envelop her.
They are her home.
If she manages this, she can handle what's to come.
If Lucy is watching from above, she wants her to be proud.
